Not sure what you are asking but a pico farad is referred to as a puff in electronics and is 10^-12 farad, pretty small really. So a pico metre is 10^-12 of a metre so a very small length. The factors of a metre going down is 10^-1decimetre, 10^-2 centimetre, 10^-3 millimetre. There is no standard prefix for 10^-4 or 10^-5 so the next one is 10^-6 micro, then 10^-9 nano, then 10^-12 pico. The full list is available here https://physics.nist.gov/cuu/Units/prefixes.html
@martinconnelly1473  I mean is there orders in which units come first?

@bme7995  I don't think you are asking a question with a certain answer. A length is a length whatever units you designate it in. With USA customary units there are a lot of different units and they have a size progression. In SI (metric) units there is only one length unit, the metre. There is a size order to USA units such as a point is smaller than an inch which is smaller than a foot which is smaller than a yard which is smaller than a fathom which is smaller than a furlong which is smaller than a mile. There are lots of intermediate customary units as well which are not in fashion such as rod, pole, perch, chain. Then there are customary units that are not based on the British Empire/French avoirdupois system that the USA still stick with. SI is designed to get rid of this proliferation of customary units and that is why it is the official measurement system in just about every country.
no i dont think order matters

@dubemforsure7184  hello Dubrem

I don't know what your starting point for how much a cup is but a litre is 100mmx100mmx100mm (10cmx10cmx10cm = 1000 cubic centimetres = 1kg of water) in volume. Since 100mm divided by 25.4 = 3.93700" this means a litre is 3.937^3 = 61.024 cubic inches. If you know what a cup is in cubic inches (14.5 I think) you can now work out a cup as a fraction of a litre. If a cup is 14.5 cubic inches then a cup would be 14.5/61.024 = 0.2376 litres so 1.2 litres will be 0.2851 cups.  It's all very hard in US customary units, simple in SI (metric) units.
